questions.question_text:
A network technician has configured a point-to-point interface on a router, however, once the fiber optic cables have been run, the interface will not come up. The technician has cleaned the fiber connectors and used an optical power meter to confirm that light is passing in both directions without excessive loss.
Which of the following is the MOST likely cause?

discussion.content:
B is correct, but an explanation would be convenient:

'Wavelength mismatch will cause serious issues with fiber optic cables. You cannot mix and match different types of cable. For example, if you connect single mode fiber to multimode fiber, you will introduce a catastrophic signal loss of up to 99%. Even connecting cables of the same type that have different core diameters can cause a loss of up to 50% of the signal strength.'

Frequency Theoretical Speed Real-World Speed
2.4 GHz (802.11n) 300 Mpbs 150 Mbps
5 GHz (802.11a) 6-54 Mbps 3 - 32 Mbps
5 GHz (802.11ac) 433 Mbps - 1.7 Gbps 210 Mbps - 1 G
5 GHz (802.11n) 900 Mbps 450Mbps
802.11n AB is not a standard. I'm guessing a web server formatting display error, as correct answer is indeed A and B

questions.question_text:
A network administrator wants to deploy a wireless network in a location that has too much RF interference at 2.4 GHz.
Which of the following standards requires the use of 5 GHz band wireless transmissions? (Select TWO)
Which of the following default ports is associated with protocols that are connectionless?

discussion.content: Answer D can also be correct.

Is this question primary intention to confuse and / or trick students?

Personally, as the link provided below is clearly indicative of, there is no such thing as a default connection-less ONLY (or even connection-orientated as a matter of fact) default port as each WKP is both UDP and TCP depending on service required and configuration in place.

In short I do not know why Port 2427 was chosen as the correct answer as the protocol that utilises cited port (Media Gateway Control Protocol (MGCP) media gateway) evidently uses BOTH UDP (connectionless) as well as TCP (connection-orientated)...

List of TCP and UDP port numbers
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_TCP_and_UDP_port_numbers

comments.content: As the question is concerned with integrity, the answer should be SHA. I agree with your explanation too.

discussion.content:
Again, even though answer A is correct, the question is rather misleading as IPSec is a suite of protocols that provides security on OSI Level 3 (Network). In very simple terms it encompasses protection services abiding to all 3 main areas (Confidentiality, Integrity, and Authentication - Not to be confused with the CIA triad*).

SHA is classified as a hash function. Simply put:

'Hash functions are the building blocks for modern cryptography. A hash function is a cryptographic algorithm which is used to transform large random size data to small fixed size data.'

Hence, it provides integrity as the process is a 'one way street'. More can be read via link below.

In short, SHA would answer the question more accurately as it does one simple job: integrity, unlike IPSec, which as mentioned earlier is a suite that includes integrity.

http://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=24833&seqNum=3

https://www.cryptomathic.com/news-events/blog/differences-between-hash-functions-symmetric-asymmetric-algorithms

*
https://www.oreilly.com/library/view/cissp-for-dummies/9781118417102/a2_13_9781118362396-ch08.html

questions.question_text: Which of the following integrity security mechanisms ensures that a sent message has been received intact, by the intended receiver?

discussion.content: Why we use stright through cable between a hub and switch?

comments.content: agreed, hub to switch should be a crossover.

discussion.content: Tricky question as a Console port on a Cisco device uses a rollover RJ45 to RS232 cable. Technically both rollover and RS232 are correct for the console port
